items.title: Mono-account and not multi-accounts :-(
items.body:
What a shame, this "wrapper" has been developed for mono-account (e.g: one laptop, one user), not for multi-accounts .... !
When used with multi-accounts, there's a permission issue (concurrency access) on the file /tmp/tika.log... What a shame :-(
Please think team and not always for only one developer...

items.title: "module 'os' has no attribute 'setsid'" error in Windows
items.body:
Hello all:

I got the following error:
`TikaServerProcess = Popen(cmd_string, stdout=logFile, stderr=STDOUT, shell=True, preexec_fn=os.setsid)
AttributeError: module 'os' has no attribute 'setsid'`

This is because os.setsid is only available in Unix based os.  In the meantime that the issue is solved, you can run the server independently using the docker image:

`docker pull apache/tika`

and running:
`docker run -d -p 9998:9998 apache/tika:<version>`

which for version 1.23 is:
`docker run -d -p 9998:9998 apache/tika:1.23`

to use it with the python library:
`parsed = parser.from_file('/tmp/pdf-sample.pdf', 'http://localhost:9998/tika')`

items.title: Exception when trying to parse on Windows 10: AttributeError: module 'os' has no attribute 'setsid'
items.body:
I'm using tika 1.23 successfully on Python 3.7.4 on one Windows 10 machine. However I installed tika 1.23.1 (the latest version) on another Windows 10 machine running Python 3.8.1, and I get an exception when I try to parse files. For example `tika.parser.from_file("PATH_TO_MY_PDF_FILE.pdf")` results in this exception: `AttributeError: module 'os' has no attribute 'setsid'.`  (NOTE: I am initializing the VM before making this call).

I dug into the tika source code, and found the offending line of code in tika.py:

`666: TikaServerProcess = Popen(cmd_string, stdout=logFile, stderr=STDOUT, shell=True, preexec_fn=os.setsid)`

The offending line references `os.setsid`, but `setsid` does not exist in the `os` module on Windows per the docs (quoted below):

https://docs.python.org/3.8/library/os.html
> os.setsid()
> 
>     Call the system call setsid(). See the Unix manual for the semantics.
> 
>     Availability: Unix.

I searched through the tika commit history on GitHub and found that this issue was introduced in this commit: https://github.com/chrismattmann/tika-python/blob/431f024d9f0862599421c27afec9076ecf29c2c3/tika/tika.py.  

Prior to the aforementioned commit, the line of code in question looked like this, with no reference to `os.setsid`:

`665: cmd = Popen(cmd_string, stdout=logFile, stderr=STDOUT, shell=True)`

Here's the diff that shows where the issue was introduced: https://github.com/chrismattmann/tika-python/commit/431f024d9f0862599421c27afec9076ecf29c2c3#diff-79bb8c4ed90a3c7e927d1091e49a6680

This issue is preventing me from using the current version of tika on Windows. I'm going to have to downgrade to version 1.23 until this is fixed.

items.title: `parser.from_file()` does not work with serverEndpoint different from localhost
items.body:
## Summary

* Setting a `serverEndpoint` different from `localhost` throws an exception. See the snippet below:

```python
import tika
from tika import parser
tika.TikaClientOnly = True
result = parser.from_file('file', 'http://10.5.0.5:9998')
```

* Apache-Tika from `logicalspark/docker-tikaserver:latest` (1.23)
* `tika-python version: 1.23`

## Steps to reproduce

* Use two container setup
  * First container hosts Apache-Tika
  * Second container could be any container having python and `tika-python` installed
* `docker-compose.yml` example:
```yml
version: '2.1'

services:
    tika-server:
      image: logicalspark/docker-tikaserver:latest
      networks:
        net:
          ipv4_address: 10.5.0.5

    consumer:
        build: ./
        networks:
          net:
            ipv4_address: 10.5.0.6
        command: ["document_consumer"]

networks:
  net:
    driver: bridge
    ipam:
     config:
       - subnet: 10.5.0.0/16
         gateway: 10.5.0.1
```



## Expected Behaviour 

* `tika-python` returns result from dockerized Apache-Tika using `parser.from_file`

## Actual Behaviour

* `ConnectionError` is thrown
* Warning `2020-01-09 18:29:43,520 [MainThread  ] [WARNI]  config option must be one of meta, text, or all; using all.` is printed
* `tika-python` calls `localhost` no matter what `parser.from_file('file', 'http://10.5.0.5:9998')` contains:

```bash
Traceback (most recent call last):
  File "<stdin>", line 1, in <module>
  File "/usr/lib/python3.7/site-packages/tika/parser.py", line 36, in from_file
    output = parse1(service, filename, serverEndpoint, headers=headers, config_path=config_path, requestOptions=requestOptions)
  File "/usr/lib/python3.7/site-packages/tika/tika.py", line 331, in parse1
    rawResponse=rawResponse, requestOptions=requestOptions)
  File "/usr/lib/python3.7/site-packages/tika/tika.py", line 547, in callServer
    resp = verbFn(serviceUrl, encodedData, **effectiveRequestOptions)
  File "/usr/lib/python3.7/site-packages/requests/api.py", line 131, in put
    return request('put', url, data=data, **kwargs)
  File "/usr/lib/python3.7/site-packages/requests/api.py", line 60, in request
    return session.request(method=method, url=url, **kwargs)
  File "/usr/lib/python3.7/site-packages/requests/sessions.py", line 533, in request
    resp = self.send(prep, **send_kwargs)
  File "/usr/lib/python3.7/site-packages/requests/sessions.py", line 646, in send
    r = adapter.send(request, **kwargs)
  File "/usr/lib/python3.7/site-packages/requests/adapters.py", line 516, in send
    raise ConnectionError(e, request=request)
requests.exceptions.ConnectionError: HTTPConnectionPool(host='localhost', port=9998): Max retries exceeded with url: /rmeta/text (Caused by NewConnectionError('<urllib3.connection.HTTPConnection object at 0x7f4665883d50>: Failed to establish a new connection: [Errno 111] Connection refused'))
```

## Analysis and Details

* `parser.from_buffer()` works as expected:

```python
import tika
from tika import parser
tika.TikaClientOnly = True
result = parser.from_buffer('Good Evening', 'http://10.5.0.5:9998')
print(result)
{'metadata': {'Content-Encoding': 'ISO-8859-1', 'Content-Type': 'text/plain; charset=ISO-8859-1', 'X-Parsed-By': ['org.apache.tika.parser.DefaultParser', 'org.apache.tika.parser.csv.TextAndCSVParser'], 'X-TIKA:content_handler': 'ToTextContentHandler', 'X-TIKA:embedded_depth': '0', 'X-TIKA:parse_time_millis': '92'}, 'content': '\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\nGood Evening\n', 'status': 200}
```

* I think the documentation is not correct by looking at the code: `def from_file(filename, service='all', serverEndpoint=ServerEndpoint ...`. 
  * Using the call `parser.from_file('file', 'http://10.5.0.5:9998')` as specified in the documentation, the variable `service` gets assigned with `http://10.5.0.5:9998` and serverEndpoint defaults to `ServerEndpoint`, which is `localhost`.
  * This also explains the Warning `2020-01-09 18:29:43,520 [MainThread  ] [WARNI]  config option must be one of meta, text, or all; using all.`

## Workaround

```python
Type "help", "copyright", "credits" or "license" for more information.
>>> import tika
>>> from tika import parser
>>> tika.TikaClientOnly = True
>>> result = parser.from_file('file', 'all', 'http://10.5.0.5:9998/')
>>> print(result)
{'metadata': {'Content-Encoding': 'ISO-8859-1', 'Content-Type': 'text/plain; charset=ISO-8859-1', 'X-Parsed-By': ['org.apache.tika.parser.DefaultParser', 'org.apache.tika.parser.csv.TextAndCSVParser'], 'X-TIKA:content_handler': 'ToTextContentHandler', 'X-TIKA:embedded_depth': '0', 'X-TIKA:parse_time_millis': '94', 'resourceName': "b'file'"}, 'content': '\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\nThis is Sparta!\n\n', 'status': 200}
>>>
```

items.title: Encoding filename as utf-8 leads to UnicodeEncodeError when filename is in Chinese
items.body:
Hi there,

Thought it may help to re-open #167 to save some time for anyone else with a similar problem.
After spending some time debugging, I came to the same conclusion as #222. 

My issue:
```
import tika
tika.initVM()
from tika import parser

parsed = parser.from_file('做好水煮牛3重點風味直逼大飯店.pdf'.encode('utf-8'))
print(parsed["metadata"])
print(parsed["content"])
```

Stacktrace:
```
Traceback (most recent call last):
  File "C:/Users/Jackie/PycharmProjects/parsepdf/parse_pdf.py", line 6, in <module>
    parsed = parser.from_file('做好水煮牛3重點風味直逼大飯店.pdf'.encode('utf-8'))
  File "C:\Users\Jackie\PycharmProjects\parsepdf\venv\lib\site-packages\tika\parser.py", line 36, in from_file
    jsonOutput = parse1('all', filename, serverEndpoint, headers=headers, config_path=config_path)
  File "C:\Users\Jackie\PycharmProjects\parsepdf\venv\lib\site-packages\tika\tika.py", line 320, in parse1
    path, file_type = getRemoteFile(urlOrPath, TikaFilesPath)
  File "C:\Users\Jackie\PycharmProjects\parsepdf\venv\lib\site-packages\tika\tika.py", line 680, in getRemoteFile
    urlp = urlparse(urlOrPath)
  File "C:\Users\Jackie\AppData\Local\Programs\Python\Python37\lib\urllib\parse.py", line 367, in urlparse
    url, scheme, _coerce_result = _coerce_args(url, scheme)
  File "C:\Users\Jackie\AppData\Local\Programs\Python\Python37\lib\urllib\parse.py", line 123, in _coerce_args
    return _decode_args(args) + (_encode_result,)
  File "C:\Users\Jackie\AppData\Local\Programs\Python\Python37\lib\urllib\parse.py", line 107, in _decode_args
    return tuple(x.decode(encoding, errors) if x else '' for x in args)
  File "C:\Users\Jackie\AppData\Local\Programs\Python\Python37\lib\urllib\parse.py", line 107, in <genexpr>
    return tuple(x.decode(encoding, errors) if x else '' for x in args)
UnicodeDecodeError: 'ascii' codec can't decode byte 0xe5 in position 0: ordinal not in range(128)
```

What fixed it:
In tika.py line 321, changing 
`    headers.update({'Accept': responseMimeType, 'Content-Disposition': make_content_disposition_header(path)})
`
to
`    headers.update({'Accept': responseMimeType, 'Content-Disposition': make_content_disposition_header(path.encode('utf-8') if type(path) is unicode_string else path)})`

In my own file, reverting
`parsed = parser.from_file('做好水煮牛3重點風味直逼大飯店.pdf'.encode('utf-8'))
`
back to
`parsed = parser.from_file('做好水煮牛3重點風味直逼大飯店.pdf')
`

items.title: Feature Request: Timeout on all requests
items.body:
For production, a timeout on requests is almost always necessary. I've forked the library and added it to the calls I use. I think a lot of others would find it beneficial to have an optional timeout parameter accepted by all public methods which end up sending a request to the Tika REST server. 

The requests library supports an optional timeout parameter. The implementation would be as trivial as passing the argument from the high-level public methods, through the callServer method, and finally passing it to the verbFn call.
